results.content:
This is one more awesome course with in depth explained of each topic covered  along with its step by step implementation to build a complete end to end project from explaining requirements, development, integration till deployment.
 I have enrolled to other awesome courses by John Thompson and Dan vega and this one too is one more a must, covering angular4 +spring boot microservices using JHipster and scalable mongoDB as back end. 

Thanks,
Zia

results.content: This course has excellent ready to use examples which are enforced with great theoretical information. The tools and technologies used all over the course are the latest and the best for the Java stack. So, after the course, you'll be a confident user of Angular 4 and Java and will be able to deploy your own project on AWS.
results.content_html: This course has excellent ready to use examples which are enforced with great theoretical information. The tools and technologies used all over the course are the latest and the best for the Java stack. So, after the course, you'll be a confident user of Angular 4 and Java and will be able to deploy your own project on AWS.

results.content:
This course soooo boring. The instructure just walks through endless lines of code. I haven't seen any red line throughout the lectures. It just goes like this: "... and here we do this..." he then quickly jumps into another section "... and here we do this ..." ... 
Probably the examples aren't bad but the lectures are tremendously boring. I have watched about 30% of the course but I have the feeling of having learnt less than nothing.

results.content:
Instructors responds to my questions with detail but….
1)	Angular 4 is outdated. An additional video or pdf with instructions it must added to this course.
2)	Many difficulties on section 9 to follow. I was expecting to type every line of code with the instructor (in video) and explain every line. Instead of that, the instructor said to me to copy his code. Programming is not always a copy-paste. That section is the main project. I did not learn how to do it and I am unable to create my own project. 
3)	In the last video, the instructor admitted that the project has not details. 
2 stars as fair evaluation and for quick response of instructor. The course is incomplete.

results.content:
Its a nice course but I think it is missing the most fundamental thing.
Its all about creating the app and deploying, which is great but that's it.

The problem of all code generators is how do you modify the code and yet being able to regenerate and regenerate without running over changes.

There are ways to do that by using @Primary, inheritance, JPA persistence events and more.

I can't imagine someone deploying an app only once. no bugs? no data migration? no schema migration? no code modification? no jhipster upgrades?
The course is missing all of that. too bad. generating an app, is easy, being able to use it as a framework is something else....
results.content_html:
Its a nice course but I think it is missing the most fundamental thing.
Its all about creating the app and deploying, which is great but that's it.

The problem of all code generators is how do you modify the code and yet being able to regenerate and regenerate without running over changes.

There are ways to do that by using @Primary, inheritance, JPA persistence events and more.

I can't imagine someone deploying an app only once. no bugs? no data migration? no schema migration? no code modification? no jhipster upgrades?
The course is missing all of that. too bad. generating an app, is easy, being able to use it as a framework is something else....

results.content:
It's all mixed up. Different project in every other recording. Created extra things outside of the recording, then just referenced. No updates to the course. 
Completely pointless addition of 'Functional Requirements Interview' section lasting over an hour of conversation. Students buying the course really, don't want to listen to an hour long requirements interview, there just isn't time for it. 
Personally, I think there is too much theory and not enough practice.
From me, unfortunately, a weak rating. Forgive me, but I did not like this course. I was disappointed.

results.content: Great course, great instructors.  Good pace until it came time to refactor RFB User to User.  At that point, the code was changed outside of the course and we were shown tons of changes in short video.  Also the course is showing jhipster working with facebook login, which is no longer an option when you set up the jhipster project.  The new way of adding social login was not shown, so we were left to try to figure that out on our own, which was not easy.  Would also like instructors or teaching assistant to answer questions and provide help.
results.content_html: Great course, great instructors. Good pace until it came time to refactor RFB User to User. At that point, the code was changed outside of the course and we were shown tons of changes in short video. Also the course is showing jhipster working with facebook login, which is no longer an option when you set up the jhipster project. The new way of adding social login was not shown, so we were left to try to figure that out on our own, which was not easy. Would also like instructors or teaching assistant to answer questions and provide help.

results.content:
If you expect to see how things are done, choose another course. You will jump from hello world!, to microservices without any stops. They do not type any example in the videos!!! Beware, Angular4!

Dan explains things, but John just talks and reads the screen (and sell InteliJ)

Do not expect an answer to your questions

response.content: We don't jump from hello world to microservices at all... and I walk through a ton of examples of how to get from a to b but I appreciate your feedback.
response.content_html: We don't jump from hello world to microservices at all... and I walk through a ton of examples of how to get from a to b but I appreciate your feedback.

results.content_html:
If you expect to see how things are done, choose another course. You will jump from hello world!, to microservices without any stops. They do not type any example in the videos!!! Beware, Angular4!

Dan explains things, but John just talks and reads the screen (and sell InteliJ)

Do not expect an answer to your questions

results.content: Great course in general, Jonh is a great instructor, I have attended all his courses here, Dan is a great discovery, agile, clear and seems to have a deep knowledge overall. As a minor flaw, I think the real-world application part should have been developed with microservices instead of the "monolithic way". I hope in the near future, as part of this course, you guys decide to, at least, plan a serie of videos refactoring this part.

response.content: Thank you so much for the kind review, Pedro. As I stated in the course I am not sure starting with microservices is the way to go unless you absolutely know you need to. With that said you aren't the only one who is interested in a course doing this so maybe we can work on something next year around that.
response.content_html: Thank you so much for the kind review, Pedro. As I stated in the course I am not sure starting with microservices is the way to go unless you absolutely know you need to. With that said you aren't the only one who is interested in a course doing this so maybe we can work on something next year around that.

results.content_html: Great course in general, Jonh is a great instructor, I have attended all his courses here, Dan is a great discovery, agile, clear and seems to have a deep knowledge overall. As a minor flaw, I think the real-world application part should have been developed with microservices instead of the "monolithic way". I hope in the near future, as part of this course, you guys decide to, at least, plan a serie of videos refactoring this part.

results.content:
(I don't have too much  experience with Angular, still I liked that the course is pushing you to learn. Great fit for my level personally.) 

This was my first review. Until the real world application part I still agree on my comment but after that part it didn't go as I expected. It turned into kind of rushing and skipping lots of things on the way. 

Another point was that I felt more comfortable when Dan Vega was teaching. John is an ocean of knowledge but honestly I think he needs to sharpen his teaching skills or adjust a bit in a way that is more efficient for online course teaching...

But still, I definetely suggest this course.

results.content:
It is by far one of the most complete courses i've ever seen.

The jhipster social is no longer included so you have to work a bit to use oauth2 (Maybe they could add this to the course in the future).

I had some problems working with spring tool suite 4.1.1 - Eclipse (I can't install intellij on my work)  with gradle and mapstruct, but maven didn't trouble at all.

Totally recommended :D
results.content_html:
It is by far one of the most complete courses i've ever seen.

The jhipster social is no longer included so you have to work a bit to use oauth2 (Maybe they could add this to the course in the future).

I had some problems working with spring tool suite 4.1.1 - Eclipse (I can't install intellij on my work) with gradle and mapstruct, but maven didn't trouble at all.

Totally recommended :D

results.content:
To me it's clear that the course was set up very quickly and the content is poor and outdated. Pity because jHipster is one of the best platforms out there but unfortunately there are not many courses on the topic.
For the most part applications were just the auto generated ones, with minor or no changes. The Angular code used is outdated doesn't work with newer versions of the framework.
My personal opinion about the instructors is that none of them have what it takes to be a good instructor. They may be good software developers (this also I do not know) but they are not good instructors. I will of course ask for a refund.

results.content:
I am really enjoying the course. There are however 2 things I'd like to mention.
First, I was expecting much more of an Angular class in terms of features and relationships e.g. navigating around a webapp. I like the content that was delivered but expected more.
Second. Instead of Angular this seems more of a course on Jhipster. Not a problem since I like working with that and am learning good information. At this time though I think the course is a couple of years old so some of the material like the yarn commands seem a bit out of date and I had a lot of problems, I ended up using google to find more recent commands. It would have been nice to have that as a warning up front.
Having said that I am liking the course and recommending it to friends.
results.content_html:

results.content: I am very happy with this course, jhipster is an amazing tool to bootstrap our applications and this course is helping me to do my real-world application. I think Jhipster is very good to bootstrap applications but to customize the application is important to understand how spring and angular works. In conclusion, I recommend this course and in the near future I will do another courses from these guys.

I think Jhipster is very good to bootstrap applications but to customize the application is important to understand how spring and angular works. results.content_html: The JHipster and Angular explanations are too fast-paced. I know the prereqs was to know Angular already, but would have like more indepth explanations

results.content: The first 8 sections provided an excellent overview of using jHipster to rapidly scaffold different types of Spring Boot + Angular projects. Unfortunately, the software versions are now quite dated which (in some cases) required many extra hours to figure out how to rewrite the code being presented so it would work properly -- and Section 9 (the real world project) turned out to be such a quagmire that I ultimately bailed on it. Great as a crash course in jHipster concepts. I'd love to see these guys release an updated version of this course.
results.content_html: The first 8 sections provided an excellent overview of using jHipster to rapidly scaffold different types of Spring Boot + Angular projects. Unfortunately, the software versions are now quite dated which (in some cases) required many extra hours to figure out how to rewrite the code being presented so it would work properly -- and Section 9 (the real world project) turned out to be such a quagmire that I ultimately bailed on it. Great as a crash course in jHipster concepts. I'd love to see these guys release an updated version of this course.

results.content: its more advertising of other software and trivial stuff like installation. was a waste of time

response.content: Would you be willing to elaborate? The description clearly states that we are going to teach you how to build Angular/Java applications using JHipster and I believe we delivered on that. I don't feel like we spent too much time on installation. This might be information you already know but I can guarantee other students appreciate having it there. I can also see from your stats that you only finished about 55% of the course. I would suggest going through the rest of course so that you get out of it what we promised. If there is anything we can do to help out please contact us.

results.content:
Dan Vega and John you did a terrific job here. Explanation was really good. Real life use case could have been better.

I would have loved to see, a complete revamped and bit more professional looking website out of JHipster. Currently I felt, like only image is attached over jhipster. 

I would have also loved to see use of Messaging and Queuing. It is such a hot topic now a days, with such a vast majority of data flowing across. Dashboard based applications could have been really handy with modern UI. I know that would have delayed slightly, but students would have learned more.

results.content:
All handwave -- extraordinary poor course.  This is advertised as a "Basic" level course but the instructor spends ABSOLUTELY no time explaining about how either Angular or Spring boot works!  Put magic tag here, annotation there, mystery file in this directory, unexplained string over there, Magic incantations is used everywhere without any hint about how anything actually works let alone how these things work together -- Horrible!!!!

If Angular and Spring Boot knowledge is supposed to be already known to the student THEN SOME WARNING SHOULD BE PUT INTO THE DESCRIPTION FOR THIS COURSE!!!
results.content_html:
All handwave -- extraordinary poor course. This is advertised as a "Basic" level course but the instructor spends ABSOLUTELY no time explaining about how either Angular or Spring boot works! Put magic tag here, annotation there, mystery file in this directory, unexplained string over there, Magic incantations is used everywhere without any hint about how anything actually works let alone how these things work together -- Horrible!!!!

If Angular and Spring Boot knowledge is supposed to be already known to the student THEN SOME WARNING SHOULD BE PUT INTO THE DESCRIPTION FOR THIS COURSE!!!

results.content: Until Section 9 was a fine course. After that just a lazy rundown of code written off screen. My favorite line: "We don't cover this topic in this course but you can by our other course where we do explain this". Also: including your one hour+ chat with the client within the official timeframe of the course... c'mon. I mean it's fine and all but only as a bonus link. Really felt like an attempt to kill two birds with one stone.  Make the app for the client ang give a quick rundown for the students. Would have liked a better quality work starting from Section  9.
results.content_html: Until Section 9 was a fine course. After that just a lazy rundown of code written off screen. My favorite line: "We don't cover this topic in this course but you can by our other course where we do explain this". Also: including your one hour+ chat with the client within the official timeframe of the course... c'mon. I mean it's fine and all but only as a bonus link. Really felt like an attempt to kill two birds with one stone. Make the app for the client ang give a quick rundown for the students. Would have liked a better quality work starting from Section 9.

results.content: Nice tutorial, Is concentrated on JHipster more and has a mandate to know Spring Boot and Angular. Some example on changing the query to DB. Also how to export JDL to DDL for MySQL configured locally on the sustem
results.content_html: Nice tutorial, Is concentrated on JHipster more and has a mandate to know Spring Boot and Angular. Some example on changing the query to DB. Also how to export JDL to DDL for MySQL configured locally on the sustem

results.content:
one of the best course i've had so far.

i've given it 4.5 since even though i'm an experienced java developer,
there some items got me confused like lombok and the need to install the plugin was not mentioned. also the HttpModule used in this tutorial is now deprecated.

however, the things i mentioned above are minor and did not stop me from learning what is being discussed.

so cheers to you Dan and John! well done!

response.content: Wow! Thanks for the amazing review John.
response.content_html: Wow! Thanks for the amazing review John.

results.content:
La construction du cours est très pédagogique. On nous explique comment monter un backend standalone, ensuite un frontend standalone. Après pour chaque composant, on présente les sujets d'une manière incrémentale. On définit les bases, on fait abstraction de la complexité. Ensuite, une fois les bases acquises, on attaque les parties complexes.

La démarche est vraiment top ainsi que la qualité du contenu !
results.content_html:
La construction du cours est très pédagogique. On nous explique comment monter un backend standalone, ensuite un frontend standalone. Après pour chaque composant, on présente les sujets d'une manière incrémentale. On définit les bases, on fait abstraction de la complexité. Ensuite, une fois les bases acquises, on attaque les parties complexes.

La démarche est vraiment top ainsi que la qualité du contenu !

results.content: The course requires a basic understanding of both Spring Boot and Angular. So far, I've learned how to set up a Spring Boot App with Angular by hand, and I am looking forward to JHipster.
results.content_html: The course requires a basic understanding of both Spring Boot and Angular. So far, I've learned how to set up a Spring Boot App with Angular by hand, and I am looking forward to JHipster.

results.content: Bien explicado hasta el momento
results.content_html: Bien explicado hasta el momento

results.content:
The only course on Udemy and the internet that teaches fullstack spring boot & angular. Big fat bonus is the JHipster section at the end of the course. I would love to see more courses like this. The only complain that I have is that this course is a bit updated at this point. I would gladly pay for an up-to-date course on JHipster! 

The instructors are very talented and I have zero issue following their instructions. Thank you!!!

response.content: Thank you for the kind words, Scott!
response.content_html: Thank you for the kind words, Scott!
